TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, mesic Typic Haploxerults

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Thornwhite gravelly loam - on an east facing convex slope of 65 percent under Douglas-fir and tanoak at an elevation of 2,220 feet. (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.  When described on September 19, 1981, the soil was dry to 50 inches and moist below).
A--0 to 2 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, friable, slightly sticky, nonplastic; common very fine, fine and few medium roots; 30 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
AB--2 to 6 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky parting to weak fine granular structure; soft, friable, slightly sticky, nonplastic; many very fine, fine and few medium roots; 30 percent pebbles; slightly acid (pH 6.4); gradual wavy boundary. (0 to 9 inches thick)
BAt--6 to 11 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) very gravelly clay loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine, fine, medium and few coarse roots; few thin patchy clay films; 35 percent pebbles; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual wavy boundary. (5 to 8 inches thick)
Bt1--11 to 20 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) very gravelly clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine, fine, medium and coarse roots; common moderately thick clay films on face of peds and line pores; 40 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobbles; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual wavy boundary. (6 to 20 inches thick)
Bt2--20 to 32 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) very gravelly clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; strong medium subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots; common moderately thick clay films on face of peds and line pores; 45 percent pebbles 5 percent cobbles; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary. (7 to 22 inches thick)
BCt--32 to 40 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) very gravelly clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; strong fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots; 45 percent gravel, 5 percent cobbles; strongly acid (pH 5.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 37 inches thick)
C--40 to 60 inches; strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) extremely gravelly sandy clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; massive; slightly hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; few fine roots; 75 percent gravel, 5 percent cobbles; strongly acid (pH 5.4).  (0 to 35 inches thick)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Humboldt County, California; about 50 years east of Shelter Cove Road in the NE 1/4, NW 1/4, sec. 12, T. 5 S., R. 1 E. in May Unit 134.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to a fractured lithic contact is greater than 60 inches.  The mean annual soil temperature is 54 degrees to 58 degrees F.  The soil between the depths of 4 and 32 inches is dry in all parts from June 15 to September 15.  The particle-size control section (6 to 26 inches) averages from 27 to 35 percent clay.  Reaction of the solum is slightly to strongly acid (in some cases the surface horizon may be neutral).
The A horizon has dry color of 10YR 4/1, 4/2, 4/3, 5/2, 5/3 or 7.5YR 4/2, 5/4 and moist color of 10YR 2/1, 2/2, 3/2, 3/3, 4/3 or 7.5YR 3/2, 4/4.  Only the upper 2 to 5 inches have moist values and chromas which qualify for a mollic epipedon.  It is loam or gravelly loam.  Rock fragment content ranges from 5 to 35 percent.
The B2t horizon has dry color of 10YR 5/3, 5/4, 6/4 or 7.5YR 5/4, 5/6, 6/4, 6/6 and moist color of 10YR 4/3, 4/4, 5/4 or 7.5YR 4/4, 4/6, 5/6.  It is very gravelly clay loam.  Rock fragment content ranges from 35 to 50 percent.  Base saturation by Hach Kit (sum of cations) 50 inches below the upper boundary of the argillic horizon ranges from 10 to 17 percent.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: This is the Kistirn in the same family and the Honeydew series.  Kistrin soils are dry in all parts of the control section for 120 days and have 60 to 70 inches of precipitation.  Honeydew soils are 20 to 40 inches deep to bedrock.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Thornwhite soils are on mountain sideslopes.  Slopes are 8 to 75 percent.  The soils formed in material weathered from sandstone or shale.  The climate is subhumid with warm, dry summers and cool, moist winters.  The average annual precipitation is 110 to 140 inches.  Mean January temperature is 40 degrees F, mean July temperature is 70 degrees F, mean annual temperature is 55 degrees F.  Frost-free season is 180-300 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the competing Honeydew and the Pardaloe and Woodin series.  Pardeloe soils lack an argillic horizon and have base saturation greater than 60 percent throughout.  Woodin soils are moderately deep and lack an argillic horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained, medium to very rapid runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: This soil is used mainly for timber production, watershed and wildlife habitat.  Natural vegetation is Douglas-fir, tanoak, Pacific madrone, golden chinkapin, sugar pine, evergreen huckleberry, ceanothus species, poison-oak, and brackenfern.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Coast Range of northern California.  The series is not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES PROPOSED:  Humboldt County, California, 1985.  Source of name is town of Whitehorn in Humboldt County, California.
OSED scanned by SSQA. Last revised by state on 9/85.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
